# Maudie Hopkins

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Maudie Hopkins  
---  
[![Maudie
Hopkins](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/White_May_2004.jpg/220px-
White_May_2004.jpg)](/wiki/File:White_May_2004.jpg "Maudie Hopkins") Maudie
Hopkins  
Born | Maudie Cecilia Acklin  
(1914-12-07)December 7, 1914  
[Baxter County, Arkansas](/wiki/Baxter_County,_Arkansas "Baxter County,
Arkansas"), U.S.  
Died | August 17, 2008(2008-08-17) (aged 93)  
[Lexa, Arkansas](/wiki/Lexa,_Arkansas "Lexa, Arkansas"), U.S.  
Nationality | [American](/wiki/Americans "Americans")  
Known for | Last publicly identified Civil War widow  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This article **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Maudie_Hopkins&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(September 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
**Maudie Hopkins** (December 7, 1914 – August 17, 2008) was an
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States") woman believed to be the last
publicly known and identified surviving widow of a [Civil
War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") veteran.

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Life
  * 2 See also
  * 3 References
  * 4 External links

## Life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maudie_Hopkins&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Life")]

Born as **Maudie Cecilia Acklin** in [Baxter County,
Arkansas](/wiki/Baxter_County,_Arkansas "Baxter County, Arkansas"), she
married **William M. Cantrell** (aged 86) on February 2, 1934, when she was
19. Cantrell had enlisted in the [Confederate States
Army](/wiki/Confederate_States_Army "Confederate States Army") at age 16 in
[Pikeville, Kentucky](/wiki/Pikeville,_Kentucky "Pikeville, Kentucky"), and
served in General [Samuel G. French's](/wiki/Samuel_G._French "Samuel G.
French") Battalion of Virginia Infantry. He was captured in 1863, and was part
of a [prisoner exchange](/wiki/Prisoner_exchange "Prisoner exchange"). He had
a previous wife, who had died in 1929. Cantrell supported her with a
[pension](/wiki/Pension "Pension") of US$25 every two or three months, and she
inherited his home in 1937. She received no further pension benefits after his
death. She remarried later in 1937, and twice thereafter, and had three
children.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

It was not especially uncommon for young women in Arkansas to marry
Confederate pensioners; in 1937 the state passed a law stating that women who
married Civil War veterans would not be eligible for a [widow's
pension](/wiki/Widow%27s_pension "Widow's pension"). The law was later changed
in 1939 to state that widows born after 1870 were not eligible for pensions.
Hopkins generally kept her first marriage a secret, fearing that the resulting
gossip (of marrying a much older man) would damage her reputation.[1]

After researching records from Arkansas and [United States Census
Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau") data,
Hopkins was certified by various historical organizations, most notably the
[United Daughters of the
Confederacy](/wiki/United_Daughters_of_the_Confederacy "United Daughters of
the Confederacy"). A spokeswoman for the UDC, Martha Boltz, has said that
there may be two other widows, one in [Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee")
and another in [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina"), but if
they are still alive, they choose to remain in anonymity.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Maudie Hopkins died on August 17, 2008, in a nursing home in [Lexa,
Arkansas](/wiki/Lexa,_Arkansas "Lexa, Arkansas"), aged 93.[2]

## See also[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maudie_Hopkins&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: See also")]

  * [Alberta Martin](/wiki/Alberta_Martin "Alberta Martin"), one of the last known Confederate war widows and the last widow whose marriage to a Confederate soldier produced offspring. She died May 31, 2004.
  * [Gertrude Janeway](/wiki/Gertrude_Janeway "Gertrude Janeway"), last known widow of a [Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American Civil War\)") veteran of the [Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War"). She died January 17, 2003.
  * Irene Triplett, daughter of Mose Triplett, is the last known Civil War pension recipient. [3]

  

## References[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maudie_Hopkins&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: References")]

  1. **Jump up ^** Barron, James. ["The 'Last Civil War Widow' Has a Successor, It Would Seem"](https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/16/business/the-last-civil-war-widow-has-a-successor-it-would-seem.html?_r=0), _The New York Times_ , June 16, 2004; retrieved January 29, 2017.
  2. **Jump up ^** [Hopkins' obituary](http://washingtontimes.com/news/2008/aug/18/maudie-cecilia-hopkins-93-confederate-widow-dies/), WashingtonTimes.com; accessed September 26, 2017.
  3. **Jump up ^** Wall Street Journal, May 11, 2014.

triviaqa_32727_129.Query Analysis: The query seeks the date of death for the last widow of the Civil War.

triviaqa_32727_129.Answer Analysis: The answer provides the specific date 'August 17, 2008' as the death date of the last widow of the Civil War.
triviaqa_32727_129.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the aftermath of the Civil War, focusing on the impact on veterans, widows, and orphans, as well as broader societal and economic effects.
